Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: What is the Economic Impact of NSF-Funded Research? Connecting the Dots Between Scientific Discovery and Entrepreneurship

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Broadly defined, entrepreneurship is the discovery, evaluation, and exploitation of profitable opportunities. In the context of NSF-funded science and engineering research, entrepreneurship can range from a graduate student starting a new company based on knowledge gained through an NSF-funded graduate research fellowship program to researchers licensing a new technology developed through an NSF-funded center. This project focuses on identifying examples of entrepreneurship in NSF-funded science and engineering research, which will help better document the economic impact of NSF-funded research (e.g., new companies started, technology licensed) as well as better understand the conditions under which scientific discovery results in entrepreneurship.
This project will survey the landscape of entrepreneurial activities engaged in by NSF-funded research projects (year 1) and conduct qualitative interviews with a representative sample of these projects (year 2). The research aims to broaden, beyond patents, the ways in which the economic impact of NSF-funded research is measured. These measures include new companies that are started based on the research, hardware and software developed during the research that are incorporated into commercial products, and technology originating from the research that is licensed to a company.
In addition to furthering the scientific understanding of entrepreneurship, a potentially transformative outcome of this research is discovering ways that NSF could better support entrepreneurship, thus increasing the potential for economic impact from science and engineering research. Furthermore, identifying practices that successful investigators use could boost entrepreneurship among researchers in an increasingly knowledge-intensive economy, as the US looks for new ways to foster start-up companies and create jobs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project developed a process for studying entrepreneurship in academic research teams. The process included: (1) identifying a sample of 1657 NSF-funded projects that would be candidates for engaging in entrepreneurship, (2) creating a process for identifying indicators of entrepreneurship-related activities for these projects (e.g., searching for keywords on websites), (3) interviewing local (Duke, UNC, NC State) recipients of NSF-funded projects about barriers and opportunities for entrepreneurship, and (4) developing a theoretical model of entrepreneurship in academic research teams (which is a completed working paper).

The theoretical model of entrepreneurship in academic research teams could impact the way that scholars view the assembly of academic research teams. In particular, academic entrepreneurship scholarship has largely focused on entrepreneurship by individuals, even though academic entrepreneurship is frequently undertaken by teams. Therefore our model focuses specifically on individual differences (e.g., risk propensity, commercialization focus) and organizational differences (e.g., entrepreneurship process knowledge, venture funding) among members who compose the team. Drawing from prior theory on team diversity, we argue that the configuration of members should moderate the relationship between entrepreneurial opportunity identification and the decision to exploit the opportunity. We develop propositions to illustrate how research team configuration matters above and beyond the aggregation of individual researchers.


Last Modified: 11/30/2015
Modified by: Jonathon Cummings
